items.item_details:
On September 21, 2011 and September 28, 2011, Bid Proposal #1018-11 – Third Party Administrator for 403(b) for SJECCD was advertised in order for the District to seek a Third Party Administrator (TPA) to continue to administer our 403(b) plan for employees. Currently, the District's TPA is Tax Deferred Solutions (TDS).
	 
The District received six respondents, which were:
Admin Partners
The OMNI Group
Tax Deferred Solutions (TDS)
TSA Consulting Group
VALIC
Zuk Financial/MidAmerica
The six respondents were evaluated by a committee that included at least one representative of the District’s three bargaining groups. TDS, Zuk Financial/MidAmerica, and The OMNI Group were selected among the six to present their services to the District because they better met the criteria that the District had established.
	 
The OMNI Group was not available for a presentation until December, failed to contact the District timely in regards to accommodating the service provider for a phone interview and did not provide us appropriate follow up information when it was requested. Because it appeared that there was a lack of enthusiasm by The OMNI Group, the committee questioned whether the provider had the capacity to take on a new client. Due to this concern, the committee collectively decided to disqualify the vendor. The remaining two service providers were extended an invitation to continue into the next phase of the evaluation. 
	 
After the presentations by the two remaining service providers, the committee was concerned that Zuk Financial/MidAmerica had an additional layer to the Third Party Administrator format. The concern was that employees and the District may have difficulties in gaining access to information regarding 403(b). If Zuk Financial/MidAmerica were to be selected, the committee had reservations that all financial transactions will take place with MidAmerica, however Zuk Financial would be the contacting agency should any inquiries be raised. A representative of MidAmerica was not present during the presentation. Furthermore, fees associated with non-participating vendors were to be deducted on a pre-tax basis, even though these fees should be net of taxes, which would require additional oversight by the District. 
	 
TDS continues to strive to get non-participating vendors to convert into a vendor pay model, thereby advocating for employees to save the transaction cost associated with non-participating vendors. They are currently undergoing negotiations with non-participating vendors to adopt the vendor pay model in hopes that it will pressure other non-participating vendors to follow suit. TDS plans to implement the fees associated with non-participating vendors beginning FY 2012-2013.
	 
It is recommendated that the Board of Trustees approve and award Bid Proposal #1018-11 – Third Party Administrator for 403(b) for SJECCD to Tax Deferred Solutions (TDS) for a period of three (3) years, subject to satisfactory performance, commencing December 14, 2011. The Agreement may renew itself automatically for one (1) consecutive year without formal amendment of Agreement on December 14, 2014 and again on December 14, 2015 for a total contract term not to exceed five (5) years.

items.item_details:
BACKGROUND:
	 
The District is interested in entering into one or more ground leases for the purpose of developing some or all of the approximately 27 acres of District property which was declared to be surplus land in 2004.  The land is located at Evergreen Valley College and currently surrounds the retail shopping center at the intersection of San Felipe Road and Yerba Buena Road.  The nature of the development will be determined in the future (Scope A).  The District is also considering the relocation of the current District Offices which may include the Workforce Institute (Scope B).  The District desires an economically desirable and aesthetically appealing project that compliments the Evergreen Valley College campus.
	 
Request for Qualifications (RFQ) and Request for Proposal (RFP) #G2010.0003 was issued to provide the district with services for the Development of District-Owned Land and Possible Relocation of the District Office.  The deadline for submittal of proposals was September 23, 2011.  Applicants were interviewed and evaluated.  The recommended consultants meet and exceed all the requirements, and in addition, the recommended consultants address the concerns associated with the Board’s interest to support locally owned and women and minority owned businesses.
	 
At the November 29, 2011 meeting the Board of Trustees received this recommendation and the related support documents as a “first reading” information item.
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the selection of consultants to provide the services for Scope A and Scope B.
	 
Scope A – Long Term Ground Lease of Surplus Land
Selected:      Andy Plescia / Gruen Gruen and Associates Team
Reasons:      Regional (Sacramento & San Francisco), but in Bay Area regularly working on other projects.  (i.e.: Ohlone College); Competitive fee structure; Small team; Presented well; Came across as comfortable/easy to work with and could communicate with stakeholders in the same manner; Works with schools and public entities in California and other states; Consensus of Selection Committee is that they are a good choice.
	 
Scope B – Relocation of District Office and Workforce Institute
Selected:      Public Property Advisors (Lisa Gillmor)
Reasons:      Locally owned small business will be submitting a women owned business application in early 2012; Works with school districts throughout California.
Note:  Public Property Advisors is a division of Gillmor and Associates
	 
FISCAL IMPLICATION:
Funding Source, Scope A: General Fund, Not To Exceed      $75,000.00
Funding Source, Scope B: Measure G 2010, Not To Exceed 3.5% Commission
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the selection of consultants to provide the services for Scope A and Scope B.

On September 26, the Board received a presentation on SJECCD’s redistricting process from Thomas Griffin from the Griffin Law Offices.  Dr. Griffin gave a presentation on the 2010 Census data and discussed its impact on SJECCD current district boundaries. Dr. Griffin provided a demographic report of each trustee area. He reviewed the 1 Person 1 Vote Rule, principles of the Voting Rights Act and those portions of the Education Code requiring that all school districts redraw their trustee areas after the federal census. Dr. Griffin also introduced the principle of 1% variance between and among contiguous trustee areas.  In other words, that we draw district boundaries that distribute the population in our service area within 1% of each other.  
		 
Since that first presentation the Board of Trustees has: 
Reviewed principles established by the Board of Trustees during the last redistricting effort in 2001 and integrate these same principles in the proposed options to be brought back to the Board (the overarching concern here is not to disadvantage minority communities and to support the election of a diverse board)
Requested GPS maps of proposed options that include major traffic arteries to make it easier to determine when a trustee area begins and ends and to compare and contrast with the current boundaries.
Presented clear timelines between the next presentation (first formal public hearing) and the end of the process
Identified and implemented outreach efforts to inform district constituents (voters) of the process underway at SJECCD  including opportunities for public input.
		 
This item presents the top two options for final review and requests that the board select the preferred option for inclusion in the SJECCD Board of Trustees Redistricting Plan for submittal to the County Elections Office.
		 
Note:  All information referenced above may be accessed on the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Website through the following link:
		 
http://www.sjeccd.edu/aboutus/board/Pages/Redistrict.aspx

items.item_details:
In 2009, San Jose Evergreen issued $46.8M of OPEB Bonds in order to pre-fund the District's liability for retiree benefits.  The liability had spiked to over $94M (total of annual projected payments), and without intervention, would have had a negative impact on the General Fund that increased every year.  Proceeds of the OPEB Bonds were deposited into the District's OPEB Trust, which is overseen by the Districtâs Retirement Board of Authority.  Together with interest earnings, the bond proceeds are expected to pay for all or a portion of the District's liability for retiree benefits.  At the time the bonds were issued, the best structure available to the District was a three (3) year direct purchase by US Bank at a rate of 4.62%.  US Bank agreed to purchase the bonds and provide immediate proceeds to the District, but would only hold the bonds until May 14, 2012.  Upon the expiration of the Initial Interest Rate Period, the Bonds are subject to a mandatory tender and remarketing, pursuant to which the bonds may be remarketed at a fixed rate, adjustable rate, or floating rate (commonly referred to as a swap).
	 
The purpose of this item is to authorize the Chancellor and Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services to negotiate and enter into contracts with consultants for the provision of services in connection with the tender and remarketing of the Bonds.  These consultants include Dolinka Group as Financial Advisor, Piper Jaffray & Co. as Underwriter/Placement Agent, and Stradling Yocca Carlson & Rauth as Bond Counsel and Disclosure Counsel.  
	 
The contracts will be deemed binding upon their execution without further action of the Board of Trustees.
	 
The costs of the consultants are expected to be paid from proceeds of the remarketing of bonds. No General Funds are expected to be required.

items.item_details:
Administrative Procedure 6380 stipulates that the District’s goal is to remove any and all barriers for a full and equal opportunity for minority-owned and women-owned businesses to provide products and services to the District. 
	 
This analysis compares two years of information (from FY 2009-2010 to FY 2010-2011) on the diversity of the District’s vendors who choose to self-identify on our Business Enterprise Certification form. The attached graphs represent the number of vendors and the associated total value of each group that provide products and services to the District.
Business Category (Graph 1A and Graph 1B) – Collects information on the multiple categories of District vendors. “Other“ categories are businesses that do not fall within the criteria of disabled, minority, small businesses, or women enterprises.
Race of Business (Graph 2A and 2B) – Collects information on the ownership and management of the business.
Diversity Among Women (Graph 3A and 3B) – Collects information on businesses that are women-owned, as well as the  ownership and management of said business.
As the analysis shows, although there have been activities of varying degrees in each category, there are striking parallels from the prior year. The District recognizes the importance of supplier diversity and by creating sound business relationships, seeks to strengthen the economic development and viability for minority-owned and women-owned businesses. 
	 
As stated in the Local Business Outreach Program for Minority-Owned, Women-Owned and Small Business (September 2011 Draft) that was presented to the Board on September 13, 2011 (Item I-4), the District’s “mission is to deliver the best value and highest quality products and services by encouraging competition among all contractors and suppliers.” This program performs a key role by providing outreach, training and educational programs through community outreach, targeted advertising, workshops, business seminars, etc. The District expects increased competition and additional opportunities for goods and services related to projects in the Measure G-2010 Bond Program that potentially can trickle into other business opportunities offered by the District.

Accreditation Recommendation 5 (Board Governance) addressed the need for systematic review and revision of board policies to ensure they are “up to date.”  The Commission was clear that this process should “include a robust ethics policy that establishes steps to be taken should a board member violate the policy.”  BP 2715 Code of Ethics/Standards of Practice was approved by the Board of Trustees on January 10, 2006.  However, this policy was deficient by Commission standards in that it did not contain language regarding a breach in ethics by one or more Board members.  
	 
The attached policy is presented for a first reading by the Board.  Page one has already been Board approved and is submitted for review only.  Page two (noted with draft watermark) is draft language reviewed by District Council and their respective constituent groups.  District Council yields page two to the Board for language changes after which they will take back to their respective constituent groups and to District Council for review.

At their meeting of September 13, 2011, the Board of Trustees requested an information item on student receivables; namely, unpaid student fees.  In addition, the Board requested specific information regarding unpaid fees that were directly ascribed to AB 540 non-resident students.  This item provides information on all students.  Staff is currently working on a separate item that addresses the issues, policies and practices regarding AB 540 non-resident students for the January agenda.  The reason for this action is that there are policies, laws and guidelines that are unique to AB 540 non-resident students that require a more detailed explanation and analysis of cohort student enrollment data.
	 
	 
Current Status of District Student Fees Receivables
	 
Page 102 of the Fiscal Year 2011-2012 Adopted Budget provided a snapshot of the District's receivables as of June 30, 2011 and a projection as of June 30, 2012.  As of June 30, 2011, the District's receivables totaled $5,948,287.  The following table illustrates the total receivables by term:

As of November 29, 2011, this number has reduced by $1,621,016 to a total student receivable of $4,327,271.
	 
The District implemented a process in Fiscal Year 2010-2011 to reduce the number of outstanding receivables.  This process (attached) incorporates sending email notifications to all students who owe $10 or more for the term.  Students who owe $20 or more after the term ends are mailed a letter advising of their liability and allowing them 30 days to satisfy their liability by paying in full or entering into a payment plan; otherwise, their account is referred to an external collection agency for continued collection efforts.
	 
The District also participates in the Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program annually, which provides for an additional avenue for the District to collect outstanding receivables.  In essence, this program allows the District to intercept a student's State Income Tax refund or lottery winnings.  Answers to frequently asked questions pertaining to the program are attached for reference.
	 
When a student registers, the tuition fees are recognized as revenue and increases the District's fund balance.  In order not to overstate the District's fund balance, the District is required to book an "allowance for bad debt" to reflect the estimated unrealized revenue (i.e., students who don't pay despite the District's efforts to collect).  This amount is currently $2,347,005 and is calculated by assuming that receivables older than three years will not be collected, that 50% of the receivables that are two years old will be collected, and that 75% of the receivables that are one year old will be collected.  Attached you will find a document that describes the process that the District follows to recognize "bad debt."

The SJECCD Chapter of Latina Leadership Network (LLN) was asked to help establish a scholarship with the SJECCD Foundation in honor of Maria Romo.  Ms. Romo was a community activist, distinguished member of LLN and long-time employee of San Jose State University.  She was also heavily involved with EOP&S programs statewide, serving on Evergreen Valley College’s advisory committee.  
	 
The amount of the scholarship has not yet been established and will depend on LLN’s fundraising efforts.  Since Ms. Romo was a single parent and an AB540 advocate, this target population will be highly considered as recipients of her scholarship.
	 
This presentation is LLN’s way of communicating this information to the Board of Trustees and the district community as a whole.

The Districtâs bond underwriting consultant, Piper Jaffray, will be presenting information on the Measure G-2010 General Obligation Bond Program.  The District successfully passed Measure G-2010, a Proposition 39 General Obligation Bond, on November 2, 2010.  
	 
As part of the initial steps for the sale of Measure G-2010 bonds, the Board of Trustees approved the Bond Project List and the Facilities Master Plan for San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College at the November 29, 2011 meeting. 
	 
The first issue of the bonds sales from the $268 million bond program will include a Series A and a Series B.  Series A issuance is expected to be approximately $70 million for facilities and equipment/technology projects for the first five years.  Series B issuance is expected to be approximately $20 million for a technology/deferred maintenance endowment.
	 
The next steps toward issuance of Series A and Series B are as follows:
	 
January 5, 2012: Presentations to bond credit rating agencies.
	 
January 10, 2012: Board of Trustees meeting to approve Series A & B bond financings.
	 
January 16 through February 10, 2012: Sale of Series A & B bonds.
	 
Mid-February: Closing of Series A & B bond financings/bond proceeds received by the District.
